quiz.question:
[Logic Error — Target Mismatch]

Passage:
"For every piece of music it has brought to attention(A), there is at least one more that it has destroyed(B)."

Choice D:
"Fashion will eventually wipe out every piece they promote."

Why is Choice D definitively wrong?
options: The passage only discusses the positive effects of fashion, but Choice D is negative
The passage treats promoted music (A) and destroyed music (B) as separate entities — but Choice D conflates them, saying fashion destroys the very pieces it promotes
The word 'Eventually' introduces a time concept that is absent from the passage
'Wipe out' and 'destroy' have completely different meanings
quiz.answer: ② Target Mismatch — A (promoted) ≠ B (destroyed)
quiz.explanation:
[Passage Logic — Separate Targets]
A (music fashion highlights) → gets promoted
As a result, a different B (music left in the shadows) → gets destroyed
→ A and B are distinct entities!

[Choice D Logic — Same Target]
Fashion promotes A, then later destroys that same A
→ Collapses A = B — a distortion of the original logic!

[Key] The TARGET of destruction is different.
Passage: Promoting A causes a separate B to disappear
Choice D: Fashion eventually destroys the very thing it promoted
quiz.action: Action Rule: In quantity/destruction sentences → first check whether A and B refer to the SAME entity or DIFFERENT entities!

quiz.question: [Action Rule Quiz — Extreme Qualifier Trap] When you see "Every", "All", "Always" in an answer choice, which error type should you suspect first?
options: Indexing Error — mistaking an example for the main idea
Targeting Error — failing to locate the keyword in the passage
Logic Error — Scope Inflation / extreme overgeneralisation
Vocabulary Error — not knowing the meaning of the word
quiz.answer: ③ Logic Error — Scope Inflation & Target Mismatch
quiz.explanation:
Extreme qualifiers like 'every piece' in Choice D are the classic Logic Error trap.

[Passage vs Choice — Scope Comparison]
Passage: 'at least one more' → at least one (limited scope)
Choice: 'every piece' → all of them (extreme overgeneralisation)

[Extreme Qualifier Checklist]
• always → does the passage say 'always'?
• every / all → does the passage mean 'all'?
• never / only → are there really no exceptions?
• eventually → is there a time dimension in the passage?
quiz.action: Action Rule: When you spot an extreme qualifier → immediately find scope-limiting language in the passage (some, often, may, at least) and compare!

quiz.question: [Q18 — Passage-to-Choice Paraphrasing] Passage: "Orchestras promote the idea of classical music. It will soothe our cares or inspire us or make us better people." Which answer choice correctly summarises the underlined part?
options: Its historical background in music
Its technical complexity for performers
Its effect on the listener
Its popularity among younger generations
quiz.answer: ③ Its effect on the listener
quiz.explanation:
[Paraphrase Chain]
'soothe our cares' → calms/relaxes us
'inspire us' → motivates us
'make us better people' → improves us
↓
All three describe what the music DOES to the person HEARING it.
= Effect on the listener

[Why the others fail]
① Historical background — passage mentions nothing about history
② Technical complexity — passage is about the audience, not performers
④ Popularity among youth — no mention of age groups or popularity
quiz.action: Action Rule: When multiple verbs describe reactions (soothe / inspire / improve) → ask 'who is experiencing this?' That subject = the paraphrase target.

quiz.question: [Q18 — Targeting Strategy] The keyword in the question is "Producers", but this exact word does NOT appear anywhere in the passage. What is the correct first action?
options: Give up on that paragraph and move to the next question
Re-read the entire passage from the beginning, scanning for the word
Shift the target to a hypernym or concrete example (e.g. record companies, promoters) and re-scan
Trust your background knowledge and pick the most plausible choice
quiz.answer: ③ Re-target: hypernym or concrete example → re-scan
quiz.explanation:
[Why the keyword hides]
Exam questions rarely repeat the passage's exact wording.
Instead they use:
• Hypernym: Producers → 'music industry', 'the business'
• Hyponym/example: Producers → 'record companies', 'label executives', 'promoters'
• Synonym: Producers → 'those who back the music'

[Worked example]
Q keyword: 'Producers'
Passage equivalent: 'Record companies' (a specific type of producer)
→ Re-targeting to 'record companies' unlocks the relevant paragraph.

[Why others fail]
① Giving up = automatic wrong answer
② Full re-read = wastes time; targeted scan is faster
④ Using background knowledge = ignores the passage = dangerous
quiz.action: Action Rule: Keyword not in passage? → Ask: 'What is the broader category? What are specific examples?' → Re-scan with that new target.

quiz.question: [Q19 — Logic Structure: Quantity Comparison] Passage: "For every piece of music it has brought to attention, there is at least one more that it has destroyed." Which choice correctly reflects the logical implication of this sentence?
options: Fashion promotes as much music as it destroys.
Fashion annihilates more music than it promotes.
Fashion only destroys the music it previously promoted.
Fashion brings more attention to music than it used to.
quiz.answer: ② Fashion annihilates more music than it promotes.
quiz.explanation:
[Quantity Logic Unpacked]
'For every 1 piece promoted (A)...
...there is at least 1 MORE destroyed (B)'

In mathematical terms: B ≥ A
→ Destroyed ≥ Promoted
→ Fashion destroys MORE (or equal) than it promotes

[Why each choice fails]
① 'as much as' implies B = A exactly — but 'at least one MORE' means B ≥ A, not B = A
③ 'only destroys what it promoted' = Target Mismatch (A = B) — the passage says A and B are different pieces
④ Comparing to the past — the passage makes no historical comparison

[The trap in ①]
'at least one more' is NOT the same as 'the same amount'.
'More' means the destroyed pile is bigger.
quiz.action: Action Rule: Spot 'at least / more than / fewer than' in the passage → translate to inequality (≥, >, <) before matching to choices. Never round to 'equal'.

quiz.question:
[Q46 — Why is Choice B wrong?]

Anecdote: A researcher refuses to accept it's 3 o'clock despite a wall clock, desk clock, and wristwatch all showing 3. His secretary rolls her eyes and says, "It is three o'clock."

Choice B (your pick): <strong>"Complexity is often disguised as simplicity."

Choice D (correct answer): "Rigid thinking can obscure the truth."

Why is Choice B a classic Indexing Error?
options: The word 'disguised' does not appear anywhere in the passage
B focuses on a surface-level image ('disguised') rather than the overall satirical point — the researcher's obsessive doubt is the real theme, not disguise
Choice B is grammatically incorrect
The researcher never uses the word 'complexity' in his dialogue
quiz.answer: ② Indexing Error — fixated on 'disguised', missed the satirical theme
quiz.explanation:
[Passage Structure]
Surface detail (example): researcher doubts clocks one by one
Punchline: secretary eye-roll → 'It IS three o'clock'
Real theme: the researcher's rigid, obsessive thinking OBSCURES a plain truth

[Why B tempts]
'Disguised' is a vivid word → eye catches it → brain builds a story around it
But 'disguised' describes a small surface detail, NOT the overall message

[Indexing Error pattern]
You indexed on: a single striking word ('disguised')
You should have indexed on: the narrative arc (absurdity → secretary's punchline → satirical point)

[Correct paraphrase chain]
Researcher's absurd stubbornness = Rigid thinking
Refusing to see the obvious fact = obscure the truth
quiz.action: Action Rule (Indexing): In anecdote/narrative passages, always ask: 'What is the PUNCHLINE or final irony?' — that is where the main theme lives. Don't let a single vivid word hijack your reading.

quiz.question:
[Q46 — Paraphrase Drill]

Complete the paraphrase chain:

① Researcher's absurd stubbornness about the clocks
   = ________ thinking

② His refusal to accept the obvious 3 o'clock fact
   = to ________ the truth

(Tap to check your answers)
quiz.answer: ① Rigid  ② obscure
quiz.explanation:
[Full paraphrase chain]
Researcher's absurd stubbornness → RIGID thinking
  (rigid = inflexible, locked into one mode of thinking)

Refusing to see the obvious → OBSCURE the truth
  (obscure = to hide or make unclear something that should be plain)

[Combined → Choice D]
'Rigid thinking can OBSCURE the truth'
= The researcher is so locked into his methodology that he cannot see the obvious answer staring at him
quiz.action: Drill habit: For every narrative passage, map: CHARACTER FLAW → abstract noun / verb. Stubbornness → rigid. Hiding the obvious → obscure.

quiz.question: [Q47 — Paraphrasing: Source vs Observer] Passage: "Both clocks run off the mains; the power could have failed." The researcher doubts both clocks for this reason. Choice A (correct): pieces of data need to be checked for mutual independence. Choice C (your pick): pieces of data need to be verified by more than one independent observer. Why is A correct and C wrong?
options: Choice A uses more technical vocabulary than Choice C
The passage is about a shared power SOURCE (the mains), not about the people observing — so the independence failure is in the data sources, not the observers
Choice C contradicts the passage because the researcher is the only observer
The word 'mutual' appears directly in the passage
quiz.answer: ② The problem is the shared power SOURCE, not the observers
quiz.explanation:
[The key line decoded]
'Both clocks run off the MAINS' 
= both clocks share the same electricity source
= if the power fails, BOTH show the wrong time simultaneously
= the two data points are NOT independent — they are linked at the source

[Paraphrase chain]
Sharing the same mains = lack of MUTUAL INDEPENDENCE
(mutual = each from the other; independence = not connected/influenced)

[Why C is wrong]
C says: 'independent OBSERVER' → the problem is with the PERSON looking
But the text says: the problem is with the POWER SOURCE they share
Watcher ≠ Source

[Visual model]
Clock A ──┐
           ├── THE MAINS (shared source) ← this is the problem
Clock B ──┘
quiz.action: Action Rule: When a character gives a reason for doubt → ask 'Is this about the DATA SOURCE or the DATA OBSERVER?' Map that precisely to the abstract choice vocabulary.

quiz.question: [Q47 — Paraphrase Drill] Passage line: "Both clocks run off the mains; the power could have failed." Complete: 'Both clocks run off the mains' = the two data sources lack ________ ________ (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: mutual independence
quiz.explanation:
[Decoding 'the mains']
The mains = the shared electricity supply
If source is shared → both clocks fail at the same time → they cannot independently confirm each other

[Paraphrase]
Shared mains → no mutual independence
(mutual = bidirectionally linked; independence = not sharing a common cause)

[Wrong trap — 'independent observer']
An observer watches the data.
A source generates the data.
The mains is a SOURCE, not an observer.
quiz.action: Drill habit: 'shared source' → 'lack of mutual independence'. Practice this substitution until it is automatic.

quiz.question: [Q48 — Paraphrasing Tone & Attitude] Passage (researcher sees wristwatch showing 3 o'clock): "An interesting association," he conceded, "but it still doesn't prove anything." Choice D (correct): possibly significant, but inconclusive. Choice C (your pick): supportive of his argument. How does each half of the sentence map to Choice D?
options: 'An interesting association' → inconclusive / 'doesn't prove anything' → possibly significant
'An interesting association' → possibly significant / 'doesn't prove anything' → inconclusive
Both halves together mean the researcher thinks it IS 3 o'clock
Both halves together mean the researcher is ignoring the wristwatch entirely
quiz.answer: ② 'interesting association' → possibly significant / 'doesn't prove anything' → inconclusive
quiz.explanation:
[1:1 Paraphrase map]
'An interesting association'  →  possibly significant
  (interesting = worth noting; association = connection — so: it might mean something)

'doesn't prove anything'  →  inconclusive
  (inconclusive = does not lead to a definite conclusion)

[Why C ('supportive of his argument') is wrong]
The researcher is NOT arguing 'it is NOT 3 o'clock'
His position is: 'I cannot yet conclude what time it is'
Supporting an argument = adding weight to a claim
But he has no positive claim — he is just withholding conclusion

[Key distinction]
Supportive → adds evidence FOR a position
Inconclusive → neither proves nor disproves; leaves question open
The researcher is firmly in 'inconclusive' territory
quiz.action: Action Rule: Two-part dialogue = two-part paraphrase. Map each clause separately before choosing. 'Interesting but not proven' = 'possibly significant but inconclusive' — memorise this pair.

quiz.question:
[Q48 — Two-Part Paraphrase Drill]

Map each phrase to its abstract equivalent:

① "An interesting association"
   = ________ ________

② "but it still doesn't prove anything"
   = but ________

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① possibly significant  ② inconclusive
quiz.explanation:
[Full map]
① 'An interesting association'
  interesting = worth noting → possibly
  association = a connection that might mean something → significant
  ∴ → possibly significant

② 'doesn't prove anything'
  no proof = no definite conclusion
  ∴ → inconclusive

[Combined]
'Possibly significant, but inconclusive'
= acknowledges the data exists AND its potential meaning
= but stops short of drawing any conclusion

[Why NOT 'supportive']
Supportive = the wristwatch backs up the researcher's claim
But the researcher has NO claim to back up — he is in a state of suspended judgment
quiz.action: Drill habit: Memorise the pair — 'interesting but unproven' = 'possibly significant but inconclusive'. This two-part structure appears constantly in GAMSAT attitude questions.

quiz.question: [Q93 — Out of Scope Trap] Passage (line 11): "'Good talk' in a special sense was their forte; the hallmark of their wit was the wisecrack, a clever insult that exposed pretension..." Q: What was the main characteristic of 'good talk'? Your pick — Choice D: insightful commentary on literature Correct — Choice B: subtle but cutting critique of other people Why is D a classic Out-of-Scope (Indexing) error?
options: The word 'literature' never appears in the passage at all
The passage mentions they were a literary lunch club, but their 'good talk' was specifically about insulting people — 'literary' is background context, not the content of their talk
Choice D uses vocabulary that is too academic for this passage
Insightful commentary is a synonym for clever insult
quiz.answer: ② 'literary' = background context, NOT the content of their talk
quiz.explanation:
[Out-of-Scope Trap Anatomy]
The passage DOES mention: literary lunch club
The passage says about their talk: clever insult / exposed pretension

→ 'literary' tells you WHAT KIND OF GROUP they were
→ It says NOTHING about the content of their actual conversations

[Indexing Error]
You picked up 'literary' (a real word from the passage context)
You indexed it as the TOPIC of their talk
But it was only the label for the club — not a description of their speech

[Correct paraphrase chain]
clever → subtle
insult / exposed pretension → cutting critique of other people
quiz.action: Action Rule (Out of Scope): If a choice uses a real word from the passage, ask: 'Is this word describing the THING the question asks about, or just background context?' Background details ≠ the answer.

quiz.question: [Q93 — Paraphrase Drill] Complete the 1:1 paraphrase map: Passage → Choice B ① clever insult → ________ critique ② insult / exposed pretension → ________ critique of other people (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① subtle  ② cutting
quiz.explanation:
[Paraphrase chain unpacked]
① clever (skilfully done, not obvious)
  → subtle (understated, not blunt)
  Both mean: the attack is indirect and crafted, not crude

② insult + exposed pretension (tore someone down, revealed their fakeness)
  → cutting critique (sharp, wounding criticism of a person)
  Both mean: the words hurt and expose weakness in others

[Combined → Choice B]
'subtle but cutting critique of other people'
= a cleverly crafted insult that exposed pretension
quiz.action: Drill habit: clever → subtle / insult + expose pretension → cutting critique. This pair tests whether you map TONE (clever=subtle) and FUNCTION (insult=cutting critique) separately.

quiz.question: [Q94 — Same-Word Trap] Passage: "...a clever insult that exposed pretension and established the superiority of the wisecracker. Such humour required linguistic deftness and a high degree of competitiveness..." Q: What was the primary purpose of Parker's style of speech at the Algonquin Club? Your pick — Choice D: encouraging sincerity by exposing pretension Correct — Choice A: establishing and enhancing her power and status Why is D wrong even though it uses the phrase 'exposing pretension' from the passage?
options: 'Exposing pretension' is used incorrectly in Choice D because pretension means sincerity

Choice D plants the exact phrase 'exposing pretension' from the passage to lure you — but the PURPOSE of that exposure was to WIN (superiority/competitiveness), not to morally improve others (sincerity)
The passage says Parker never actually exposed pretension
Choice D is wrong because Parker was not sincere herself
quiz.answer: ② Same-word lure — 'exposing pretension' was a weapon for dominance, not moral encouragement
quiz.explanation:
[Same-Word Trap Anatomy]
The passage says: exposed pretension → to ESTABLISH SUPERIORITY
Choice D says: exposing pretension → to ENCOURAGE SINCERITY

Same action (exposing pretension), completely different PURPOSE

[Intent analysis]
Establish superiority = I want to WIN / be on top
Encourage sincerity = I want others to be more honest/genuine

The passage is clear: high degree of COMPETITIVENESS
→ These people were competing for dominance, not preaching virtue

[Correct paraphrase chain]
established superiority + competitiveness → establishing and enhancing POWER AND STATUS

[Rule]
When a choice copies exact passage words → immediately check: does it preserve the original PURPOSE or distort it?
quiz.action: Action Rule (Same-Word Trap): Passage words in a choice = automatic suspicion. Re-read the original context and ask: 'What was the PURPOSE or result?' Match that, not the surface words.

quiz.question: [Q94 — Paraphrase Drill] Complete the map: Passage → Choice A ① established the superiority → establishing and ________ her... ② superiority / competitiveness → power and ________ (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① enhancing  ② status
quiz.explanation:
[Paraphrase chain unpacked]
① established → establishing AND enhancing
  'established' = set it up initially
  'enhancing' = continued to build on it
  Together: not just created status, but kept growing it

② superiority + competitiveness → power and STATUS
  superiority = being above others in rank/ability → power
  competitiveness = drive to beat others → status (social standing)

[Key distinction from D]
The PURPOSE is dominance (power/status) — NOT moral improvement (sincerity)
Choice D hijacks the action ('exposing pretension') and invents a false noble motive
quiz.action: Drill habit: superiority + competitiveness → power and status. These two passage words compress into one choice phrase. Practise mapping compound evidence to single abstract terms.

quiz.question: [Q95 — Distinction Trap: funny vs good-humoured] Passage: "Parker was a funny, but not a good-humoured, writer. The careful reader... can easily see that their wit and elegance costume moods of emptiness and despair. (...) acerbic fictions..." Q: What does being 'good-humoured' involve for the author? Your pick — Choice A: possessing a natural ability to make people laugh Correct — Choice D: having a positive outlook on life Why does Choice A describe 'funny', NOT 'good-humoured'?
options: Making people laugh and being good-humoured are identical concepts
The passage explicitly separates the two: 'funny BUT NOT good-humoured' — A is the paraphrase of 'funny'; good-humoured = the opposite of emptiness/despair/acerbic = a positive outlook on life
Choice A is wrong because Parker was not naturally funny
The author never defines what good-humoured means in the passage
quiz.answer: ② 'funny BUT NOT good-humoured' — the passage splits them into two distinct concepts
quiz.explanation:
[The BUT NOT construction]
Parker = funny ✓  AND  good-humoured ✗

This means funny ≠ good-humoured (they are different things)

[Mapping each term]
funny = makes people laugh = Choice A (natural ability to make people laugh)
good-humoured = NOT(emptiness + despair + acerbic)
             = the opposite of those = positive outlook on life = Choice D

[Why A is the wrong answer]
A correctly describes 'funny'
But the question asks what 'good-humoured' means
The passage explicitly says she was funny but NOT good-humoured
→ Choosing A conflates the two concepts the passage carefully separates

[Negation logic]
good-humoured = opposite of: emptiness, despair, acerbic
             = fullness of spirit, hope, warmth
             = positive outlook on life
quiz.action: Action Rule (BUT NOT trap): When the passage uses 'X but not Y', the question may ask about Y. Never use the description of X to define Y. Map each side of the contrast independently.

quiz.question: [Q95 — Negation Paraphrase Drill] The passage says Parker was funny but NOT good-humoured. Her writing reveals: emptiness, despair, acerbic tone. Complete the logic chain: ① funny = ability to make people ________ (→ Choice A — the WRONG answer) ② good-humoured = opposite of emptiness/despair/acerbic = ________ ________ on life (→ Choice D — the CORRECT answer) (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① laugh  ② positive outlook
quiz.explanation:
[Full negation map]
funny → makes people LAUGH → Choice A
  (this is a real quality of Parker's — but it answers the WRONG question)

good-humoured → NOT (emptiness + despair + acerbic)
  emptiness ↔ fullness / meaning
  despair ↔ hope / optimism
  acerbic ↔ warm / gentle
  All three point to: POSITIVE OUTLOOK ON LIFE → Choice D

[The trap]
A is a true statement about Parker
But the question asks about good-humoured, which the passage says she is NOT
Therefore A describes what she HAS, not what good-humoured means

[Key habit]
When you see 'X but NOT Y' — define Y by negating the evidence given for X's absence
quiz.action: Drill habit: good-humoured = opposite of (despair + acerbic + emptiness) = positive outlook on life. Practise the negation logic: what would a person WITHOUT despair and acerbity be like?

quiz.question: [Q41 — Who is being criticised, and for what?] Passage: "They put the needs of the disadvantaged above the needs of the system." → Portillo implies governmental childhood associations CANNOT do this. Q: Portillo implies a criticism of governmental childhood associations for being unable to ______. Your pick — C: provide a close familial environment for children Correct — A: put the child's needs first What type of error led to choosing C?
options: Vocabulary error — 'familial' was misunderstood
Indexing + Targeting error: drawn to the 'successful family' paragraph's emotional emphasis, then searched in the wrong place — the criticism target is the GOVERNMENT SYSTEM, not family environment
Logic error — 'familial environment' is an extreme overgeneralisation
Paraphrasing error only — 'familial' and 'needs first' mean the same thing
quiz.answer: ② Indexing + Targeting error — 'family' language ≠ the government's criticism point
quiz.explanation:
[Targeting: Who is being criticised?]
Question asks about: governmental childhood associations
Criticism = what they CANNOT do

[Key passage line]
'They put the needs of the disadvantaged above the needs of the system'
→ The IDEAL is: child's needs > system's needs
→ The CRITICISM of gov't bodies: they do the reverse — system > child

[Why C is wrong]
C = 'provide a close familial environment'
→ This describes a feature of successful FAMILIES
→ The passage does discuss family, but that is not the criticism of gov't bodies
→ You indexed on the emotionally vivid 'family' section instead of the policy criticism section

[Correct paraphrase chain]
'put the needs of the disadvantaged above the needs of the system'
= put the CHILD'S needs FIRST
(disadvantaged = children in care; above the system = first priority)

[3-question diagnostic]
① Who is the subject of criticism? → governmental childhood associations
② What is the specific failure? → not prioritising the child over the system
③ Where in the passage? → the line about 'needs of the disadvantaged'
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q41): Every question about criticism — identify: WHO is criticised + WHAT specific failure. Never let emotionally vivid paragraphs (family warmth) pull your eye away from the policy-critique paragraph.

quiz.question: [Q41 — Paraphrase Drill] Complete the map: Passage → Choice A ① 'the needs of the disadvantaged' = the ________ 's needs ② 'above the needs of the system' = put those needs ________ (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① child  ② first
quiz.explanation:
[Paraphrase chain]
① 'the disadvantaged' in context = children in government care (the vulnerable ones)
   → child's needs

② 'above the needs of the system' = prioritised over everything else
   → first (placed above all else)

[Combined → Choice A]
'put the child's needs first'
= put the needs of the disadvantaged above the needs of the system

[Why it was missed]
The phrase 'needs of the disadvantaged' sounds abstract/political
But in this passage context it directly refers to: the children themselves
Always ask: 'Who are the disadvantaged being referred to here?'
quiz.action: Drill habit: 'needs of the disadvantaged above the system' = 'child's needs first'. The abstraction hides a simple priority statement — always translate quantity/priority language into plain terms first.

quiz.question: [Q43 — Who is the policy TARGET?] Passage (final paragraph): "...encourage men and women who decide that, for a time, parenthood will be a full-time responsibility." Context: restoring a recognition of marriage into the tax and benefits system. Q: The policy described would enable people to ______. Your pick — D: encourage children to make the most of their familial environment Correct — A: take time off full-time work to look after their children Why is D wrong?
options: D is wrong because the passage never mentions children benefiting from family
D gets the policy TARGET wrong — the policy supports PARENTS (to step back from work), not children (to change their behaviour). The subject of the final paragraph is 'men and women', not children.
D is an extreme overgeneralisation of the passage's argument
D uses vocabulary not found anywhere in the passage
quiz.answer: ② Wrong policy target — policy supports PARENTS, not children's behaviour
quiz.explanation:
[Policy target identification]
Passage says: 'encourage MEN AND WOMEN who decide... parenthood will be a full-time responsibility'
Target = parents (men and women)
Action = choosing to dedicate full time to parenthood (stepping away from paid work)

[Why D fails]
D says: 'encourage CHILDREN to make the most of their familial environment'
Target = children ← WRONG
Action = children optimising their home situation ← not in the passage

[The tax/benefits system link]
'Restoring recognition of marriage into tax and benefits'
= financial support for families where a parent steps back from full-time work
= enabling: take time off full-time work to look after their children (Choice A)

[Paraphrase chain]
'parenthood will be a full-time responsibility' (choosing parenting over paid work)
= 'take time off full-time work to look after their children'

[3-question diagnostic]
① Who is the subject of criticism/policy? → parents (men and women)
② What is the policy enabling them to do? → step back from paid work for parenthood
③ Who is NOT the target? → children themselves
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q43): Before matching to choices, answer: 'Who does this policy/action apply TO?' Parent vs child vs government — these three are constantly swapped in GAMSAT traps. Lock the target first.

quiz.question: [Q43 — Paraphrase Drill] Complete the map: Passage → Choice A ① Subject: 'men and women who decide...' = ________ (not children, not government) ② 'parenthood will be a full-time responsibility' = take ________ off full-time ________ (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① parents  ② time / work
quiz.explanation:
[Paraphrase chain]
① 'men and women who decide...' = PARENTS making an active choice
   The policy is aimed at them, not at children's behaviour

② 'parenthood will be a full-time responsibility'
   = treating parenting as a full-time job
   = stepping away from paid employment to do it
   = take TIME OFF full-time WORK (to look after their children)

[Combined → Choice A]
'take time off full-time work to look after their children'
= men and women choosing parenthood as a full-time responsibility

[The D trap decoded]
D sounds plausible because the passage IS about families
But D makes CHILDREN the subject of the policy action
The passage makes PARENTS the subject — always check the grammatical subject
quiz.action: Drill habit: 'parenthood as full-time responsibility' = 'take time off full-time work'. The key compression: full-time parenthood → leaving full-time employment. Also always ask: who is the grammatical SUBJECT of the policy sentence?

quiz.question:
[Pattern Drill — 3-Question Diagnostic]

Your recent error pattern (Q41, Q43, Q93, Q94):
① Drawn to emotionally vivid paragraphs (family warmth)
② Confused policy/criticism TARGET (gov't vs parent vs child)
③ Missed paraphrase connection

Before choosing an answer in a policy/criticism question,
which THREE questions must you answer first?
options: What is the tone? / What vocabulary is used? / How long is the paragraph?
Who is the SUBJECT of the question? / Who is the policy/criticism TARGET? / Who is being criticised or supported? — lock all three before scanning choices
Which paragraph is most vivid? / Which choice uses passage words? / Which option sounds most academic?
What is the main theme? / What is the author's tone? / What does the title suggest?
quiz.answer: ② Subject / Target / Criticised-or-supported — lock these three first
quiz.explanation:
[The 3-Question Diagnostic]
Q1: Who is the SUBJECT of the question?
    → governmental bodies? parents? children? the author?

Q2: Who is the policy/criticism TARGET?
    → the entity being enabled, criticised, or discussed
    → Q41: gov't bodies / Q43: parents / Q93: the speaker's wit / Q94: Parker

Q3: Is this entity being criticised or supported?
    → Q41: criticised (for failing to prioritise child)
    → Q43: supported (policy enables parents to step back)

[Why this works]
GAMSAT policy passages constantly swap:
  government ↔ parent ↔ child
One wrong swap = wrong answer

[Trap immunity]
Once you lock Subject + Target + Direction (criticise/support)
→ most decoy choices become obviously off-target
→ Q41 C (family environment) → wrong target
→ Q43 D (children's behaviour) → wrong target
quiz.action: Action Rule (META): For ANY question involving policy, criticism, or social commentary — answer the 3-question diagnostic BEFORE reading the choices. Write S/T/D (Subject / Target / Direction) in the margin if needed.

quiz.question: [Q53 — Paraphrase: What is Zetlin's criticism based on?] Passage (opening): "One could argue that there is too much emphasis on the stereotypes and not enough on the gender." → The film claims to tackle gender issues but actually just plays with stereotypes. Q: Zetlin's criticism of Dating the Enemy is based on her ______. Your pick — C: belief that films which tackle gender issues end up perpetuating stereotypes Correct — A: perception of a difference between what the film achieves and the stated aims of its director Why is A correct and C wrong?
options: C is wrong because the passage never uses the word 'perpetuating'

C over-generalises to ALL films that tackle gender issues — the passage only criticises THIS film. A correctly captures the gap between the director's stated aim (investigate gender) and what the film actually does (reinforce stereotypes).
A is correct because Zetlin praises the director's intentions explicitly
C is wrong because stereotypes are not mentioned in the passage
quiz.answer: ② A captures the aim↔reality GAP; C overgeneralises to all films
quiz.explanation:
[Passage structure decoded]
Director's STATED AIM: 'playing with sexual stereotypes to investigate modern relationships'
What the film ACTUALLY DOES: 'too much emphasis on the stereotypes, not enough on the gender'
→ Gap between intention and execution = Zetlin's criticism

[Paraphrase chain → Choice A]
'stated aims of its director' = Huberman said the film investigates gender
'what the film achieves' = actually just emphasises stereotypes
'perception of a DIFFERENCE between' = Zetlin notices the gap

[Why C tempts]
C uses the passage's own word 'tackle' and concept 'perpetuating stereotypes'
→ Classic same-word trap (Q94 pattern repeating!)
But C makes a claim about ALL films that tackle gender issues
→ The passage only criticises THIS specific film

[Scope error in C]
Passage scope: this film, this director
C scope: all films that tackle gender issues
→ Scope inflation = wrong
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q53): When a choice uses exact passage words ('tackle', 'stereotypes') → immediately check SCOPE. Is it about this specific case, or all cases? The passage = specific. Overgeneralised choice = trap.

quiz.question:
[Q53 — Paraphrase Drill]

Passage:
'too much emphasis on the stereotypes and not enough on the gender'
→ gap between director's stated aim and actual result

Complete → Choice A:

① Director's stated aim = the ________ aims of its director
② What the film actually does ≠ aim = a ________ between what the film achieves and the stated aims

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① stated  ② difference (perception of a difference)
quiz.explanation:
[Map]
Director SAID: film will investigate gender relationships
Film ACTUALLY: over-emphasises stereotypes instead
↓
Zetlin NOTICES this contradiction
= 'perception of a DIFFERENCE between what the film achieves and the stated aims'

[Key word: 'stated']
Stated aims = what the director publicly claimed
Not what was achieved — what was promised

[Why C fails the scope test]
'Films which tackle gender issues' = many films
Passage = only about Dating the Enemy
C inflates one film's failure into a universal law
quiz.action: Drill habit: 'stated aims' = what the director claimed / 'what the film achieves' = actual result. When these two diverge → that gap IS the criticism.

quiz.question: [Q55 — Why inverted commas around 'madcap'?] Passage (line 12): "...deflecting attention to another 'madcap' episode of mistaken identity." Zetlin puts 'madcap' in inverted commas to suggest the film's episodes are ______. Your pick — A: amusing but disquieting Correct — B: tired and hackneyed What does 'madcap' in inverted commas signal?
options: The word 'madcap' is being used in its literal dictionary definition

Inverted commas signal scepticism — Zetlin is distancing herself from the word, implying the episodes are NOT genuinely madcap but rather stale and overused (hackneyed). 'Disquieting' (Choice A) comes from a different sentence about the film's tone, not this line.
Inverted commas mean the word is a direct quote from the director
Zetlin uses inverted commas to emphasise how creative and zany the episodes are
quiz.answer: ② Inverted commas = scepticism/irony → the episodes are NOT genuinely madcap = hackneyed
quiz.explanation:
[Inverted commas = distancing device]
When a writer puts a word in inverted commas:
→ They are NOT endorsing the word
→ They are questioning or mocking it
→ 'so-called madcap' = it PRETENDS to be wild/zany but isn't really

[Paraphrase chain → Choice B]
'madcap' (in inverted commas) = supposedly wild/zany, but actually...
→ tired (worn out, overused)
→ hackneyed (clichéd, unoriginal)
= the episodes are predictable, not genuinely surprising

[Why A ('amusing but disquieting') is wrong]
'Disquieting' comes from line 8: 'faintly disquieting'
→ This describes the FILM'S OVERALL TONE, not the 'madcap' episodes
→ You correctly identified 'disquieting' from the passage BUT targeted the wrong line
→ This is a Targeting error embedded inside a Paraphrase question

[Context clue]
Line 4: 'so-called battle of the sexes' — same inverted-commas technique
= Zetlin also puts 'so-called' on 'battle of the sexes' to signal it's a cliché
→ Consistent pattern: Zetlin uses distancing language to signal staleness
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q55): Inverted commas around a word = the writer is being ironic or sceptical. Ask: 'Is the writer praising or mocking this word?' Mocking + overused concept = hackneyed/clichéd. Do NOT borrow 'disquieting' from a different line.

quiz.question:
[Q55 — Paraphrase Drill]

Zetlin writes: 'madcap' (in inverted commas)

Complete:

① Inverted commas signal the author is being ________ about the word
   (= she does NOT genuinely mean it)

② 'madcap' (ironic) = the episodes are ________ and hackneyed
   (= stale, overused, unoriginal)

③ TRAP: 'disquieting' (line 8) describes the film's ________ tone,
   NOT the 'madcap' episodes

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① ironic / sceptical  ② tired  ③ overall
quiz.explanation:
[3-point map]
① Inverted commas = irony/scepticism = 'so-called'
② 'madcap' (ironic) → tired and HACKNEYED
   hackneyed = clichéd, done so many times it's boring
③ 'disquieting' is on line 8, describing the general film tone
   It does NOT describe the specific 'madcap' episodes on line 12

[Line targeting discipline]
Line 8: 'faintly disquieting' → film's overall tone
Line 12: 'madcap' (inverted commas) → specific episode quality = hackneyed
Always note WHICH LINE the question cites before selecting evidence
quiz.action: Drill habit: inverted commas = irony = the opposite of the word's positive meaning. 'Madcap' normally = wildly spontaneous. In inverted commas = actually stale and predictable = hackneyed.

quiz.question: [Q56 — Targeting: What kind of humour does Zetlin find?] Passage: • 'This stuff can be amusing' (line 8) — humour exists • 'the plotting is awkward and dances around these serious issues' (line 9) • 'deflecting attention' (line 12) — avoids direct engagement • 'mistaken identity' as the comic device — a classic cliché Q: Zetlin finds the humour in Dating the Enemy ______. Your pick — B: clever but contrived Correct — D: subtle and provocative Your notes say 'Step 2 (타겟팅) 오류 — 단어를 잘 몰랐음'. Which word was likely the targeting/vocabulary obstacle?
options: 'Subtle' — this word does not appear in the passage so it cannot be the answer

'Contrived' (억지스러운) in Choice B sounds plausible, but the passage says humour IS amusing/clever — it never says it feels forced. 'Provocative' (도발적인) in D aligns with 'disquieting' (불안감을 주는) + the film trying to make a serious point. The block was likely 'provocative' or 'contrived'.
'Amusing' — this word is too simple to cause an error
'Dull' in Choice A — the passage clearly says the film is funny so A is immediately eliminated
quiz.answer: ② 'contrived' sounds plausible but passage doesn't support forced/artificial; 'provocative' = disquieting
quiz.explanation:
[Passage evidence for Choice D]
'amusing' → subtle (the humour works, but not overtly)
'faintly disquieting' + 'trying to make a serious point' → provocative
(provocative = designed to make you think/feel uncomfortable = disquieting)

[Why B fails]
'clever' — partially supported (the film IS amusing/has wit)
'contrived' — means forced, artificial, unnatural
The passage does NOT say the humour feels forced or fake
The criticism is about AVOIDANCE (deflecting, dancing around), not artificiality

[Vocabulary pair to memorise]
contrived (억지스러운) = artificially constructed, feels fake
provocative (도발적인) = challenging, designed to disturb or provoke thought

[Key paraphrase chain → D]
'faintly disquieting' → provocative (both = unsettling, thought-provoking)
'amusing' → subtle (present but understated)

[Targeting lesson]
The question asks about ZETLIN'S ASSESSMENT of the humour
Evidence is spread across lines 8-10: amusing + disquieting + awkward plotting
Don't stop at line 8 ('amusing') — gather all humour-related evidence first
quiz.action:
Action Rule (Q56): For 'author's assessment' questions — collect ALL evaluative words across the passage before choosing. 'Amusing' alone = incomplete. 'Amusing + disquieting' together = subtle + provocative = Choice D.

Vocab to drill: contrived(억지스러운) ≠ provocative(도발적인/불안을 자아내는)

quiz.question: [Q56 — Paraphrase Drill] Map the passage evidence to Choice D: ① 'This stuff can be amusing' (line 8) → ________ (understated, not loud) ② 'faintly disquieting' + 'trying to make a serious point' → ________ (designed to challenge or unsettle) Bonus — vocabulary check: ③ contrived = ________ (억지스러운) ④ provocative = ________ (도발적인) (Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① subtle  ② provocative  ③ artificially forced / feels fake  ④ challenging / designed to unsettle or provoke thought
quiz.explanation:
[Full evidence map → Choice D]
amusing → SUBTLE
  subtle = present but understated, not obvious comedy
  the humour is there but quiet — not slapstick

faintly disquieting + serious point → PROVOCATIVE
  provocative = makes you think, challenges, unsettles
  disquieting (불안감을 주는) = same emotional register as provocative

[Vocabulary contrast]
contrived: the humour is MANUFACTURED, feels artificial
  → passage does NOT support this — the humour genuinely amuses
provocative: the humour CHALLENGES the viewer
  → passage DOES support this — it tries to make a serious point

[Collection discipline]
Needed TWO lines to build Choice D:
Line 8 → subtle / Line 8-9 → provocative
Stopping at line 8 only = missing half the evidence
quiz.action: Drill habit: amusing → subtle / disquieting → provocative. These two passage words compress perfectly into Choice D. Always collect the full set of evaluative words before mapping to choices.

quiz.question: [Q49 — Targeting: What is the REAL target word?] Passage (line 15): "...it has often been termed 'primitive' in a particularly pejorative sense..." Q: Those who call Neolithic art 'primitive' are being ______. The question is NOT asking: 'Is calling this art primitive accurate or inaccurate?' The question IS asking: 'What is the ATTITUDE of people who use that word?' Which word in the passage directly answers that attitude question?
options: 'primitive' — this is the key target word because the question quotes it
'pejorative' — this word describes the MANNER/ATTITUDE in which 'primitive' is used, which is exactly what the question asks about
'digress' — because the author steps aside to defend Neolithic art
'termed' — because this word means to call or label something
quiz.answer: ② 'pejorative' — describes the attitude behind using the word 'primitive'
quiz.explanation:
[Targeting discipline]
The question quotes 'primitive' as a HOOK
But the real answer is in the MODIFIER: 'in a particularly PEJORATIVE sense'

[What pejorative means]
pejorative = expressing contempt or disapproval
= looking down on something
= treating as inferior

[Attitude question → tone word]
Q: What are they BEING? (= what is their attitude?)
A: They are being CONDESCENDING (= looking down on it)
= pejorative → condescending ✓

[Why 'primitive' is the distractor]
'Primitive' is vivid and emotionally loaded
→ You respond to it emotionally
→ But the question is about TONE, not content
Always ask: 'What is the manner/attitude of the person using this word?'
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q49 Targeting): When a question quotes a word and asks 'what are they BEING?' — don't target the quoted word. Target the TONE MODIFIER around it. Here: not 'primitive' but 'pejorative sense'.

quiz.question: [Q49 — Paraphrase: pejorative → which choice?] Passage: '...termed primitive in a particularly pejorative sense' pejorative = expressing contempt, looking down on something Your pick — B: accusatory (비난하는, 고발하는) Correct — C: condescending (깔보는, 우월한 척하는) What is the critical difference between these two tones?
options: Accusatory and condescending mean the same thing — both involve a negative attitude

Accusatory = 'you did something WRONG' (requires a fault/crime) — there is no wrongdoing in calling art primitive. Condescending = 'I am SUPERIOR to you' (intellectual snobbery) — this perfectly matches pejorative (looking down on something as inferior)
Condescending is wrong because the passage says the author defends Neolithic art
Accusatory is correct because the people who use 'primitive' are attacking the artists
quiz.answer: ② accusatory requires a FAULT; condescending requires only SUPERIORITY — pejorative = condescending
quiz.explanation:
[Tone precision map]
accusatory (비난하는)
= 'You did something WRONG'
= requires: a crime, a fault, a blame
= e.g. accusatory tone in a courtroom, pointing a finger at wrongdoing

condescending (깔보는)
= 'I am BETTER/SUPERIOR than you'
= requires: intellectual or social snobbery
= e.g. 'Oh, how quaint, these primitive little figures...'

[Does calling art 'primitive' imply wrongdoing?]
No — no one is being accused of a crime
It implies the speaker feels SUPERIOR, ABOVE the art
→ condescending ✓

[Pejorative → condescending: the paraphrase]
pejorative = expressing contempt = treating as inferior
= the speaker positions themselves as ABOVE the subject
= exactly what condescending means

[Your sounding-board logic and why it failed]
Your logic: primitive → bad label → attacking → accusatory
Correct logic: pejorative → contemptuous → superiority → condescending

[The pivot point]
accusatory: directed at WRONGDOING
condescending: directed at INFERIORITY
Neolithic art is not guilty of anything — it's just being looked down upon
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q49 Paraphrase): accuse = blame for a FAULT. condescend = imply INFERIORITY. When the passage signals contempt/dismissal (pejorative), the tone is condescending, not accusatory. No crime = no accusation.

quiz.question:
[Q49 — Vocabulary Precision: Tone Words]

A critic says: "This so-called 'primitive' art is really just the clumsy scratching of people who lacked proper technique."

This critic's tone is best described as ______.
(Apply the accusatory vs condescending distinction)
options: accusatory — because the critic is attacking the Neolithic artists
condescending — because the critic positions themselves as intellectually superior, dismissing the art as crude and inferior without accusing anyone of wrongdoing
ironical — because the critic puts 'primitive' in inverted commas
metaphorical — because 'clumsy scratching' is not literal
quiz.answer: ② condescending — superiority + dismissal, no accusation of wrongdoing
quiz.explanation:
[Applying the distinction]
Does the critic accuse someone of a FAULT or CRIME? → No
Does the critic position themselves as SUPERIOR? → Yes ('clumsy scratching', 'lacked technique')
→ condescending ✓

[Accusatory would look like...]
'These artists DELIBERATELY misled viewers about their technical abilities'
= blaming them for intentional wrongdoing
= accusatory

[Condescending looks like...]
'These poor primitive people couldn't help being so crude'
= dismissive from a position of superiority
= condescending

[The pejorative link]
pejorative sense = expressing contempt = condescending attitude
This is why 'pejorative' → 'condescending' is the exact paraphrase

[Tone word bank to remember]
accusatory → blame / fault / wrongdoing / charge
condescending → superior / dismissive / patronising / looking down
pejorative → contemptuous / demeaning / belittling
ironic → saying opposite of what is meant
quiz.action: Drill habit — tone word test: Before choosing a tone word, ask: 'Does this require a FAULT (accusatory) or just SUPERIORITY (condescending)?' Pejorative always maps to condescending in GAMSAT passages.

quiz.question:
[Q49 — Full Chain Drill]

Complete the sounding-board logic chain:

❌ Wrong chain (your original path):
primitive → bad label → ________ → accusatory

✅ Correct chain:
pejorative → ________ → intellectual superiority → ________

Bonus vocab check:
③ pejorative = ________ (한국어)
④ condescending = ________ (한국어)
⑤ accusatory = ________ (한국어)

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ❌ attacking  ✅ contemptuous / condescending  ③ 경멸적인  ④ 깔보는/거드름 피우는  ⑤ 비난하는/고발하는
quiz.explanation:
[Full chain comparison]
❌ Wrong: primitive → bad label → ATTACKING → accusatory
  Attack implies: fault, wrongdoing, something to be blamed
  The passage has none of this

✅ Correct: pejorative → CONTEMPTUOUS → intellectual superiority → CONDESCENDING
  Contempt: looking down without accusing
  Superiority: 'I am above this'
  Condescending: the attitude of someone who looks down

[The pivot question]
Ask: 'Is someone being blamed for wrongdoing?' → No → not accusatory
Ask: 'Is someone being looked down upon as inferior?' → Yes → condescending

[Vocabulary summary]
pejorative (경멸적인): the word or expression belittles its subject
condescending (깔보는): the PERSON using it acts superior
accusatory (비난하는): the person charges someone with a fault
ironic (아이러니한): saying the opposite of what is meant
metaphorical (은유적인): using figurative language
quiz.action: Drill habit: The 3-second tone test — 'fault or inferiority?' FAULT → accusatory. INFERIORITY → condescending. Run this test every time you see a tone/attitude question.

quiz.question: [Q8 — Paraphrase: Why are these words confused?] Passage (promotional blurb): "...words alike in sound and related in meaning, that frequently get misused and confused" Q: The examples suggest the book deals ______. Your pick — C: only with sorts of words confused by people who parade an extensive vocabulary Correct — B: with a wide range of words which, for a combination of reasons, are often confused What is the core paraphrase error in choosing C?
options: C is wrong because the book does not deal with vocabulary

C invents a cause ('extensive vocabulary users') not mentioned in the passage — the passage lists THREE distinct reasons (sound, meaning, misuse). When multiple reasons appear, the correct choice acknowledges 'combination of reasons', not a single invented cause.
C is wrong because 'parade' is a negative word and the blurb is positive
C is wrong because the book covers more than 1600 words
quiz.answer: ② C invents a single cause; passage has THREE reasons → 'combination of reasons'
quiz.explanation:
[Passage structure → 3 reasons]
① alike in SOUND (phonetic similarity)
② related in MEANING (semantic overlap)
③ frequently MISUSED (usage error)
→ These are three distinct, independent reasons
→ No single cause dominates
→ = 'combination of reasons' (Choice B)

[Why C is over-inference]
'People who parade an extensive vocabulary'
= people who show off their word knowledge
= nowhere in the passage
The passage never restricts its audience to vocabulary-show-offs
→ pure invention / over-reading

[Paraphrase chain → B]
alike in sound + related in meaning + misused
= wide range of words + combination of reasons + often confused

[Key rule: multiple causes = 'combination']
Whenever the passage lists 2+ independent reasons for something
→ the correct choice will say 'combination', 'variety', 'range of reasons'
→ Any choice that gives ONE single cause = likely wrong
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q8): Count the number of reasons/factors in the passage. If 2+, immediately flag 'combination of reasons' as the target paraphrase. Single-cause choices are almost always traps when the passage gives multiple factors.

quiz.question:
[Q8 — Paraphrase Drill]

Passage lists THREE reasons words are confused:
① alike in ________
② related in ________
③ frequently ________

→ These three together = 'for a ________ of reasons' (Choice B)

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① sound  ② meaning  ③ misused  → combination
quiz.explanation:
[Full map]
sound + meaning + misused = three independent causes
= 'a combination of reasons'

[Why B beats C]
B: 'combination of reasons' = accurately reflects 3 causes
C: 'people with extensive vocabulary' = invented, zero passage support

[Rule to drill]
Multiple listed factors in passage → 'combination/variety/range' in correct choice
Always count factors before choosing
quiz.action: Drill habit: Before choosing, count how many reasons the passage gives. 3 reasons listed = the answer will say 'combination'. One-cause choices collapse multiple factors and are usually wrong.

quiz.question: [Q9 — AND Condition: Both criteria must be met] Passage condition: 'alike in sound AND related in meaning' → BOTH must be true simultaneously Your pick — C: 'decent' and 'descend' Correct — D: 'consequent' and 'subsequent' Why does C fail the AND test?
options: C fails because 'decent' and 'descend' do not sound similar

C passes the SOUND test (de-cent / de-scend sound similar) but FAILS the MEANING test — they have completely unrelated meanings. In an AND condition, one fail = total fail. D passes both: similar sound AND both mean 'following/coming after'.
C fails because both words are adjectives
D is correct because both words appear in the dictionary
quiz.answer: ② C passes sound but fails meaning — AND condition requires BOTH to pass
quiz.explanation:
[AND condition logic]
condition: sound ✓ AND meaning ✓ = PASS
if EITHER fails → total FAIL

[Testing C: 'decent' / 'descend']
sound: de-CENT / de-SCEND → similar ✓
meaning: decent = morally good / descend = to go down → unrelated ✗
result: FAIL (meaning criterion not met)

[Testing D: 'consequent' / 'subsequent']
sound: con-SE-quent / sub-SE-quent → similar ✓
meaning: consequent = following as a result / subsequent = coming after → related ✓
result: PASS ✓

[Why C tempts]
'decent' and 'descend' LOOK similar on the page
They also SOUND similar when spoken
→ Sound check passes → brain stops checking
→ Meaning check skipped → error

[AND trap pattern]
This question type appears repeatedly in GAMSAT
Format: 'X and Y' condition in passage
Trap choices: pass one condition visibly, hide failure of the other
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q9): When passage gives 'X AND Y' condition — build a 2-column checklist. Test EVERY choice against BOTH columns. C passes column 1 (sound) but fails column 2 (meaning). Only D passes both. One fail = eliminated.

quiz.question:
[Q9 — AND Condition Drill]

Test each pair against the TWO criteria:
'alike in SOUND' AND 'related in MEANING'

C: 'decent' / 'descend'
   Sound alike? ____  Meaning related? ____  → Pass or Fail? ____

D: 'consequent' / 'subsequent'
   Sound alike? ____  Meaning related? ____  → Pass or Fail? ____

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: C: Sound ✓ / Meaning ✗ → FAIL  |  D: Sound ✓ / Meaning ✓ → PASS
quiz.explanation:
[C: decent / descend]
Sound: de-CENT / de-SCEND → similar sounds ✓
Meaning: decent (도덕적으로 올바른) / descend (내려가다) → completely unrelated ✗
→ AND condition: FAIL

[D: consequent / subsequent]
Sound: con-SE-quent / sub-SE-quent → similar sounds ✓
Meaning: consequent (결과로 뒤따르는) / subsequent (그 후에 오는) → both in 'following/after' semantic family ✓
→ AND condition: PASS

[The AND rule]
A chain is only as strong as its weakest link
In AND conditions: one failure = total failure
Never stop at the first criterion passing
quiz.action: Drill habit: Write two columns — SOUND | MEANING — and tick each separately. Never let a ✓ on sound make you skip the meaning check. Both columns must be green.

quiz.question: [Q10 — Vocabulary Precision: physical vs mental state] Distinguish the meanings: • occupied = a place or person is in use / busy (physical/external) • preoccupied = mentally absorbed, lost in thought (mental/internal) Your pick — A: occupied = full / preoccupied = in preparation Correct — B: occupied = engaged / preoccupied = engrossed Why is B the only pair that correctly maps both words?
options: B is correct because 'engaged' and 'engrossed' both start with 'en-'

B correctly maps BOTH: 'engaged' = busy/in use (matches occupied's physical sense) AND 'engrossed' = mentally absorbed/deeply focused (matches preoccupied's mental sense). Choice A fails both: 'full' ≠ occupied (too physical/spatial) and 'in preparation' ≠ preoccupied (preparation is future-focused, not mental absorption).
A is wrong only because 'full' is too informal
'In preparation' is wrong because it appears nowhere in the passage
quiz.answer: ② B maps both correctly: engaged (busy) = occupied / engrossed (mentally absorbed) = preoccupied
quiz.explanation:
[Word meaning analysis]
occupied:
= a seat is taken, a person is busy with a task
= external, physical state of being in use
= → engaged (busy, involved in something)

preoccupied:
= your mind is elsewhere, absorbed in thought
= internal, mental state
= → engrossed (deeply mentally absorbed)

[Why A fails]
'full' → spatial/quantity meaning → wrong dimension
'in preparation' → future-oriented activity → ≠ mental absorption

[Physical vs Mental distinction]
occupied: 자리가 차있는 / (일로) 바쁜 → EXTERNAL
preoccupied: 다른 생각에 잠겨있는 → INTERNAL/MENTAL

[Vocabulary pairs to memorise]
occupied ↔ engaged (바쁜, 사용 중인)
preoccupied ↔ engrossed (몰두한, 정신이 딴 데 가있는)
engrossed ↔ absorbed, captivated, immersed
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q10): For paired word questions, classify each word as PHYSICAL or MENTAL state first. Then match: physical→physical, mental→mental. Occupied = physical/external. Preoccupied = mental/internal.

quiz.question:
[Q10 — Vocabulary State Drill]

Classify and complete:

① occupied = ________ state (물리적/정신적?)
   synonym = ________ (Choice B)

② preoccupied = ________ state (물리적/정신적?)
   synonym = ________ (Choice B)

Bonus:
③ engrossed (한국어) = ________
④ engaged (한국어, 이 문맥에서) = ________

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ① physical / external → engaged  ② mental / internal → engrossed  ③ 몰두한, 푹 빠진  ④ 바쁜, 관여하고 있는
quiz.explanation:
[State classification]
occupied = PHYSICAL/EXTERNAL state
  = a space is taken, a person is busy doing a task
  = engaged (actively involved in something)

preoccupied = MENTAL/INTERNAL state
  = your mind is elsewhere, absorbed in something
  = engrossed (deeply mentally focused on something)

[Memory hook]
PRE-occupied: the 'pre-' suggests your mind is already SOMEWHERE ELSE
= mentally elsewhere = engrossed in other thoughts

[Why A's choices fail]
full = quantity/spatial, not activity
in preparation = future planning, not mental absorption
quiz.action: Drill habit: occupied (바쁜, 사용 중) = engaged / preoccupied (딴 생각 중) = engrossed. The pre- prefix signals mental preemption — your mind is already taken.

quiz.question: [Q12 — Paraphrase: What is the key feature of this dictionary?] Passage: A 'dictionary of confusibles' = a dictionary that groups PAIRS/SETS of easily confused words together Q: The most likely characteristic of Room's Dictionary of Confusibles is that ______. Your pick — B: it has the words indexed by subject rather than alphabetically Correct — C: it often directs users who look for an entry under one word to look under another Why does C follow directly from 'confusibles' and B does not?
options: B is wrong because all dictionaries are alphabetical

C directly follows from the concept of 'confusibles': if brusque and brisk are confused pairs, looking up 'brusque' redirects you to 'brisk' (the paired word). B invents 'subject indexing' — the passage only mentions words are confusable, not that they are grouped by topic/subject.
C is correct because the author explicitly states this in the blurb
B is wrong because the book has over 1600 words which is too many for subject indexing
quiz.answer: ② C follows logically from 'confusibles' structure; B invents 'subject indexing' with no passage support
quiz.explanation:
[What 'confusibles' means structurally]
A confusibles dictionary pairs or groups easily confused words
e.g. brusque ↔ brisk / baroque ↔ rococo / notable ↔ noticeable

[How this creates the C feature]
If you look up 'brusque', the dictionary says:
'See also: brisk' (its confusible pair)
→ you are directed FROM one word TO another
→ = 'directs users who look under one word to look under another'

[Why B is over-inference]
'Indexed by subject' = organised by topic (e.g., medical words, legal words)
The passage says: confusable words (sound + meaning overlap)
Nothing about subject/topic grouping
→ B is a logical-sounding feature of a dictionary, but NOT this specific one

[Paraphrase chain → C]
'confusibles' (confused pairs) → one word points to its confused partner
= directs users from one entry to look under another

[The passage-evidence rule]
The question asks about THIS dictionary's characteristic
→ evidence must come from the blurb, not from general dictionary knowledge
→ 'subject indexing' = general dictionary knowledge, not passage-based
quiz.action: Action Rule (Q12): 'Most likely characteristic' questions — derive the answer from the SPECIFIC CONCEPT described in the passage ('confusibles' = pairs). Do not use general background knowledge about dictionaries. Ask: 'What must be true given THIS dictionary's unique feature?'

quiz.question:
[Q12 — Logic Drill: What follows from 'confusibles'?]

If this dictionary pairs confused words (e.g. brusque ↔ brisk),
complete the logical chain:

① A user looks up 'brusque'
② The dictionary shows: 'brusque' is often confused with ________
③ Therefore the dictionary ________ users from one entry to look under ________

→ This directly describes Choice ____

(Tap to check)
quiz.answer: ② brisk (its confusible pair)  ③ directs / another  → Choice C
quiz.explanation:
[Logic chain]
brusque ↔ brisk = a confusible pair
Looking up 'brusque' → dictionary says 'see also: brisk'
= redirected from one word to the other
= 'directs users who look under one word to look under another' = Choice C

[Why this is NOT Choice B]
B says 'indexed by subject'
= e.g., medical terms together, legal terms together
= completely different organisational principle
= nothing in the blurb supports this

[The reasoning pattern]
Don't ask: 'What do dictionaries usually do?'
Ask: 'What MUST this specific type of dictionary do, given its name?'
Confusibles = pairs → one entry points to its pair → redirects users
quiz.action: Drill habit: For 'characteristic of X' questions — derive from the DEFINITION of X, not from background knowledge. 'Confusibles dictionary' → must redirect between paired entries → Choice C.

quiz.question:
[Unit 164 — Pattern Summary]

Your four errors in Unit 164 share a common root cause.
Which best describes the SINGLE habit that would have prevented all four?

Q8 (combination of reasons) / Q9 (AND condition) / Q10 (physical vs mental) / Q12 (confusibles logic)
options: Reading the passage more slowly from beginning to end

Return to the EXACT passage structure before choosing: count conditions (AND = check both), count causes (multiple = 'combination'), classify word dimensions (physical/mental), derive from passage concept not background knowledge
Learning more vocabulary before attempting GAMSAT passages
Eliminating obviously wrong choices first before reading the passage
quiz.answer: ② Return to exact passage structure — count, classify, derive. Don't infer beyond it.
quiz.explanation:
[4 errors, 1 root cause: insufficient passage anchoring]

Q8: Passage had 3 causes → should have counted → 'combination'
Instead: invented one cause (extensive vocabulary users) ✗

Q9: Passage had AND condition → should have tested BOTH → D passes both
Instead: tested only SOUND, skipped MEANING check ✗

Q10: Passage had physical/mental distinction → should have classified
Instead: matched by surface similarity (full ≈ occupied?) ✗

Q12: Passage had specific concept ('confusibles') → should have derived
Instead: used general dictionary knowledge ✗

[The 4 micro-rules]
① Count causes → multiple = 'combination'
② AND = 2-column checklist, both must pass
③ Classify by dimension (physical/mental, cause/effect, etc.)
④ Derive from passage concept, not background knowledge

[Score implication]
Fixing these 4 habits = 4+ extra correct answers per section
= approximately 3-5 points improvement on S1
quiz.action: Meta Rule (Unit 164): Before choosing ANY answer — ask: How many factors? (count) / Is there an AND condition? (checklist) / What dimension is this? (classify) / Am I using passage evidence or my own knowledge? (derive). 4 questions, 4 extra marks.
